passages.text: 2Q25 PPOP/NPAT beat on solid **gaining** and OPEX reduction

PSBC's 1H25 PPOP grew strongly by +14.6% y-y to RMB79.7bn (thanks to OPEX reduction from agency fee rate cut), while 1H25 NPAT came in slower, up +0.8% y-y to RMB49.2bn (acct. for 56% of FY25E consensus estimate). 2Q25 PPOP came in stronger-than-expected, up +23.5% y-y (an acceleration vs. +6.2% y-y in 1Q), thanks to solid trading gain (+34% y-y) and OPEX control (-9.8% y-y). 2Q25 NPAT came in slower, +4.8% y-y (albeit still a decent turnaround vs. -2.6% y-y in 1Q) due to higher credit cost (+4bp y-y in 2Q25). ROA/ROE fell -2bp/-89bp y-y to 0.54%/10.5% in 2Q25. PSBC announced 1H25 DPS of RMB0.1230 (-16.7% y-y), mainly due to equity dilution of -17.2% from recapitalization, more than offsetting the 1H25 NPAT growth of +0.8% y-y. Payout ratio has been kept unchanged at 30% in 1H25 (flat y-y)

**Key Positives** — Loan growth was decent, +1.9% q-q/+10.1% y-y in 2Q25 (vs. +5.0% q-q/+9.8% y-y in 1Q), mainly driven by decent corporate loan growth (+4.5% q-q, likely driven by increased lending to utility / wholesale retail trade sectors, +34%/+26% h-h in 1H) while retail loan growth remains muted, +0.4% q-q in 2Q25 (mainly dragged by credit card loan book, -6% h-h in 1H25); With decent loan growth of +1.9% q-q outpacing deposits expansion (+0.8% q-q in 2Q), LDR was raised by +0.63ppt q-q to 59.2% in 2Q25. Fee income accelerated to +16.3% y-y in 2Q25 (vs. +8.8% y-y in 1Q25), to account for 7.3% of total revenue in 2Q (+0.8ppt y-y), likely thanks to improved wealth mgmt./ investment banking fee income, +48%/+41% y-y in 1H25 amid improved investor sentiment. **Dealing gain** grew +30.7% q-q/+34.0% y-y to reach RMB13.3bn in 2Q25, to form 14.7% total revenue in 2Q (+3.4ppt q-q/+3.4ppt y-y) likely thanks to more favorable bond market condition in 2Q; CIR was reduced by -7.7ppt y-y to 53.7% in 2Q25, likely thanks to reduced deposit agency fee payment to the bank's Parent Group after fee rate re-negotiation (-8.9% y-y in 1H25); **CET1/ tier-1/Total CAR** were up by +131bp/+127bp/+123bp q-q to 10.52%/12.13%/14.57% in 2Q25, thanks to RMB130bn equity recapitalization, which boosted CET1 ratio by 139bp based on 2Q25 RWA. (Continue on P.2)
Source: Powered by dataCentral
Price (29 Aug 25 16:10)HK$5.41Target priceHK$5.72Expected share price return5.7%Expected dividend yield4.4%Expected total return10.2%Market CapHK$107,422MUS$13,783M

Citi Research is a division of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. (the "Firm"), which does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the Firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision. Certain products (not inconsistent with the author's published research) are available only on Citi's portals.

Key Negatives — NIM was down - 2bp q- q to 1.69% in 2Q25, likely due to lower asset yield (- 9bp q- q by our estimate in 2Q25, likely due to weak credit demand and ongoing loan repricing), more than offset the positive from lower funding cost (- 7bp q- q in 2Q by our estimate, possibly thanks to past deposit rate cut bearing fruit). Asset quality: NPL ratio was up +1bp q- q to 0.92% in 2Q25, likely due to increased retail NPL ratio, +10bp h- h to 1.38% in 1H25 (w/ higher NPL ratio observed across consumption loan/mortgage/micro loans/ credit card loans, up +14bp/+9bp/+9bp/+7bp h- h to 1.47%/0.73%/2.29%/1.55% in 1H25), more than offsetting the modest corporate NPL ratio reduction by - 5bp h- h to 0.49% in 1H25. After adding back write offs, gross NPL formation rate picked up +12bp y- y to 0.57% in 2Q25. Meanwhile, both SML ratio/overdue >3month loan ratio were up +13bp q- q/+12bp h- h to 1.21% in 2Q25/0.87% in 1H25. NPL to overdue >3month loan ratio fell 15.5ppt h- h to 105% in 1H25, indicating likely loosened NPL recognition standard in 1H25. Against asset quality pressure, while PSBC has been stepping up credit cost (+4bp y- y to 47bp in 2Q25), NPL coverage has remained on a downtrend, reaching 259.6% in 2Q25 (- 6.55ppt q- q).

Implications — We see market to react positively to PSBC's solid PPOP/NPAT growth of +23.5%/+4.8% y- y in 2Q25, both of which rank the fastest among Big6 bank peers. However, due to recapitalization, we note that PSBC faces larger- than- peers equity dilution of 17.2% in 2025E, which could bring down its PSBC- A/- H 25E dividend yield to 3.6%/4.3% only, which does not stand out from Big6 bank peers.

Established in 2007, PSBC is the fifth- largest commercial bank by assets and the youngest large bank in China. PSBC has the largest branch network among Chinese banks, with 39,680 self- operating + agency branches as of 1H19, covering \(99\%\) of the cities and counties in China, and it has one of the largest retail customer bases among peers with c.600mn customers as of 1H19. PSBC strategically focuses on providing financial services to retail customers, SMEs and agriculture- related sectors, and has delivered stronger than peers' loan growth in the past few years supported by a leading deposit franchise.

We rate PSBC- H as Buy. We view PSBC as a unique play among Chinese banks as it has the defensiveness of a large bank - given a clean balance sheet, less exposure to risky loans and a strong excess provision buffer - and at the same time enjoys the better growth and profitability prospects of a mid/small retail bank given less national service pressure/ fewer regulatory constraints, and significant untapped potential from its existing customer base. In particular, PSBC stands out with a leading deposit franchise and an LDR that is the lowest among peers, while its lending & intermediary businesses remain under- developed and present significant growth potential.

We use an Economic Value Added (EVA) model to determine our target price of HK\$5.72 for PSBC H- shares. EVA is commonly used to value banks, especially when rate liberalization has kicked off and ROE is likely to drop. Our assumptions include a sustainable ROE of \(11\%\) and long- term growth of \(5\%\) . We adopt a cost of equity of \(14.7\%\) , which suggests a fair 2026E P/B of 0.59x.

Key downside risks that could mean the PSBC- H shares fail to achieve our EVA- based target price include: 1) worse than expected economic conditions in China; 2) greater than expected declines in LPR and/or market interest rates; 3) PSBC may be called on to undertake 'national service' given it is a major state- owned bank; and 4) PSBC's retail transformation is subject to execution risk and may take longer than expected.

Analysts' compensation is determined by Citi Research management and Citigroup's senior management and is based upon activities and services intended to benefit the investor clients of Citigroup Global Markets Inc. and its affiliates (the "Firm"). Compensation is not linked to specific transactions or recommendations. Like all Firm employees, analysts receive compensation that is impacted by overall Firm profitability which includes investment banking, sales and trading, and principal trading revenues. One factor in equity research analyst compensation is arranging corporate access events between institutional clients and the management teams of covered companies. Typically, company management is more likely to participate when the analyst has a positive view of the company.

Citi Research stock recommendations include an investment rating and an optional risk rating to highlight high risk stocks. **Risk rating** takes into account both price volatility and fundamental criteria. Stocks will either have no risk rating or a High risk rating assigned.

**Investment Ratings:** Citi Research investment ratings are Buy, Neutral and Sell. Our ratings are a function of analyst expectations of expected total return ("ETR") and risk. ETR is the sum of the forecast price appreciation (or depreciation) plus the dividend yield for a stock within the next 12 months. The target price is based on a 12 month time horizon. The Investment rating definitions are: Buy (1) ETR of 15% or more or 25% or more for High risk stocks; and Sell (3) for negative ETR. Any covered stock not assigned a Buy or a Sell is a Neutral (2). For stocks rated Neutral (2), if an analyst believes that there are insufficient valuation drivers and/or investment catalysts to derive a positive or negative investment view, they may elect with the approval of Citi Research management not to assign a target price and, thus, not derive an ETR. Citi Research may suspend its rating and target price and assign "Rating Suspended" status for regulatory and/or internal policy reasons. Citi Research may also

suspend its rating and target price and assign "Under Review" status for other exceptional circumstances (e.g. lack of information critical to the analyst's thesis, trading suspension) affecting the company and/or trading in the company's securities. In both such situations, the rating and target price will show as "—" and "–" respectively in the rating history price chart. Prior to 11 April 2022 Citi Research assigned "Under Review" status to both situations and prior to 11 Nov 2020 only in exceptional circumstances. As soon as practically possible, the analyst will publish a note re-establishing a rating and investment thesis. Investment ratings are determined by the ranges described above at the time of initiation of coverage, a change in investment and/or risk rating, or a change in target price (subject to limited management discretion). At times, the expected total returns may fall outside of these ranges because of market price movements and/or other short-term volatility or trading patterns. Such interim deviations will be permitted but will become subject to review by Research Management. Your decision to buy or sell a security should be based upon your personal investment objectives and should be made only after evaluating the stock's expected performance and risk.

Catalyst Watch/Short Term Views ("STV") Ratings Disclosure: Catalyst Watch and STV Upside/Downside calls: Citi Research may also include a Catalyst Watch or STV Upside or Downside call to indicate the analyst expects the share price to rise (fall) in absolute terms over a specified period of 30 or 90 days in reaction to one or more specific near-term catalysts or events impacting the company or the market. A Catalyst Watch will be published when Analyst confidence is high that an impact to share price will occur; it will be a STV when confidence level is moderate. A Catalyst Watch or STV Upside/Downside call will automatically expire at the end of the specified 30/90 day period. The Catalyst Watch will also be automatically removed if share price performance (calculated at market close) exceeds 15% against the direction of the call (unless over- ridden by the analyst). The analyst may also remove a Catalyst Watch or STV call prior to the end of the specified period in a published research note. A Catalyst Watch/STV Upside or Downside call may be different from and does not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects a longer- term total absolute return expectation. For purposes of FINRA ratings- distribution- disclosure rules, a Catalyst Watch/STV Upside call corresponds to a buy recommendation and a Catalyst Watch/STV Downside call corresponds to a sell recommendation. Any stock not assigned to a Catalyst Watch Upside, Catalyst Watch Downside, STV Upside, or STV Downside call is considered Catalyst Watch/STV No View. For purposes of FINRA ratings distribution- disclosure rules, we correspond Catalyst Watch/STV No View to Hold in our ratings distribution table for our Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside rating system. However, we reiterate that we do not consider No View to be a recommendation. For all Catalyst Watch/STV Upside/Downside calls, risk exists that the catalyst(s) and associated share- price movement will not materialize as expected.
